BE

So here's SocGen.

11:11 am
BE

Third capital increase since 2009: ArcelorMittal (Ba2/BB/BB+ neg) has this morning announced a proposed capital raise of $3bn as well as the sale of its 35% minority stake in Gestamp for c.$1bn. This is the group’s third capital increase since 2009. The group raised $3.2bn in 2009 and $3.5bn in 2013, including the MCNs. The Mittal family has committed to take up its pro-rata entitlement (c.$1.1bn), while banks will underwrite the remaining amount. Both the rights issue and stake sale are expected to close in H116.

BE

Reported leverage to decline by 0.8x; credit ratings likely to stabilise at mid-BB: Pro forma FY15 net debt would be reduced by $4bn to below $12bn, leaving reported net debt/EBITDA at 2.2x vs 3x before the rights issue/asset disposal and vs the 4.25x covenant limit. While positive, the $4bn debt reduction plan will likely have only a modest impact on the group’s debt protection credit metrics, especially considering the weak guidance for FY16 EBITDA. We estimate that adjusted FFO/net debt will remain below 15% in FY16, which would be commensurate with the current BB ratings. Hence, we expect the current ratings to be affirmed on the back of today’s announcements.

BE

FY15 results in line; FY16 EBITDA guidance weak: FY15 EBITDA came in at $5.2bn ($1.1bn in Q4), in line with consensus expectations. Reported net debt declined by $1bn during Q415 to $15.7bn, mainly due to a working capital release ($0.8bn). Management sees FY16 EBITDA above $4.5bn (vs current consensus and SG at $5.4bn), breakeven free cash flow was helped by lower capex (-$0.3bn yoy), lower cash interest (-$0.2bn yoy), the dividend suspension and lower cash taxes. Pro forma liquidity remains strong with $14bn in cash and available credit lines vs $2.3bn and $2.7bn of debt maturing in 2016 and 2017 respectively and an average debt maturity of 6.2 years. Alongside its FY15 results, the group unveiled a five-year strategic roadmap (Action 2020 plan) aiming to improve EBITDA and free cash flow performance during the period.

11:12 am
BE

Maintain Sell CDS: Post this morning’s announcement, MTNA cash bonds are up to 5.75pt higher and MTNA 5yr CDS is now trading at 12.5/14.5 (-3 today). We remain sellers of protection at current levels. MTNA cash bonds are less attractive in our view (Hold) given the large positive basis.

BE

And Jefferies.

BE

Balance Sheet Outlook Improved, But is it Enough? In recent months, the investment
community has viewed a MT capital raise as a when, not if, situation as the need to bolster
the balance sheet was becoming a top priority. Today's announcement of a cumulative $4bn of pending cash inflow (capital raise and asset sale), would lower the YE15 Net Debt balance from $15.7bn to c.$11.7bn, implying a Net Debt/EBITDA multiple 2.2x, leaving significantly more headroom vs covenant levels of 4.25x. Liquidity as of YE15 stood at $10.1bn. These are steps in the right direction, but MT is running out of levers to pull, and the assumption of
continued spot margins may indeed be generous given a potential sustained deterioration
of global steel market conditions.

11:13 am
BE

(@Boncoeur: casualty of the commodities selloff, I guess.)

BE

Action 2020. In addition, MT introduced an "Action 2020" plan which targets a return to
EBTIDA/t levels of greater than $85/t, vs 4Q15 of $56/t. Notably, this plan is absent a recovery in steel prices and raw materials and is to be based off structural EBITDA improvements of $3bn and targeted FCF greater than $2bn. The largest planned driver of the per tonne profitability improvement is to be Europe, benefiting from a $1bn transformation plan including clustering of sites. However, we remain concerned that MT is not adequately addressing its upstream crude steelmaking footprint (so as to better improve its fixed cost base) nor its product suite (so as to boost ASPs) as seen recently by peers.

11:22 am
BE

AAL's continues to struggle with free cash generation on spot commodity
prices. We estimate US$0.5 billion free cash to the equity in 2017 and US$1
billion on an unlevered basis. The latter compares to net debt of US$11.5
billion by the end of 2016 (all on spot prices). This places significant pressure
on AAL's equity valuation. AAL should provide further details at the full year
results on 16 Feb on how much negative cash flow it can remove with the
sales or closure of assets that are currently burning cash. It should also
become clearer what the cash cost are of executing that strategy. We still think
it will be hard to achieve substantial improvements in sustainable FCF without
incurring substantial cash outflows upfront.

11:34 am
BE

Concerns about potential competition from delivery networks are substantially overdone, in our view: We continue to see JUST EAT operating in a different market to services like Deliveroo, and continue to believe that both services can grow very well side by side. From a consumer perspective, we think a substantial part of the population is unable to consistently afford the additional cost of ordering from an average Deliveroo restaurant (including both
the delivery fee that is charged, together with higher food prices on average) compared to an average JUST EAT restaurant. For example, while Deliveroo started in London, it is not present in all parts of London, and instead has prioritised building a presence in parts of other cities in the UK and internationally. From the perspective of the restaurants, mass market and independent restaurants are more likely to appear on JE than Deliveroo, and more upscale casual dining restaurants are more likely to appear on Deliveroo than JE. Indeed, where Deliveroo is very well established with several hundred restaurants and JE also has several hundred restaurants in the same area, the overlap of restaurants is minimal – e.g. in Soho, there are just c2% of overlapping restaurants on the platforms. Many of JE’s restaurants are small, independent, family-run and unlikely to outsource the food delivery to a nonfamily member and pay away a higher commission for the privilege.

BE

"Many of JE’s restaurants are small, independent, family-run and unlikely to outsource the food delivery to a nonfamily member and pay away a higher commission for the privilege."

BE

Yes! Exactly! It's a fragmenting market and they're at the crap end!

11:34 am

PM

angry smile

BE

And, Barclays.

11:35 am
BE

Recent concern around the stock has centered on the risk of new competition such as we have seen with GRUB in the US, and particularly the risk from Uber and Amazon. This deal shows that new competition still needs to execute and money on its own is not enough. Rocket bought these assets in February 2015 and has struggled to compete with JE. Companies like Deliveroo, Uber and Amazon are specialized in the logistics component and their respective cost models are not that well suited for the JE price-point. Whilst we agree that entry barriers are not high, they are many as the battle is won at a postcode level. The models of specialized delivery companies work only in highly urbanized areas and therefore form only a potential risk in certain areas. We therefore reiterate Overweight.

BE

And Goldman.

BE

We believe these acquisitions are positive for JUST EAT as it consolidates
leadership positions in its most competitive markets in which a clear #1
player had not been established. We would expect consolidation to lead to
high growth and rapidly rising profitability as significant synergies can be
achieved on marketing, which can then be focused on driving channel shift
rather than share gain vs. competitors (as we have seen in Russian
classifieds and forecast in JUST EAT’s Australian business). Based on
management’s targets, the aggregate implied transaction multiples are
c.18.9x/c.9.5x 2017/18 EV/EBITDA vs. JUST EAT’s current multiples of
21x/13x/10x 2016/17/18E EV/EBITDA, noting the shares have de-rated c.25%
ytd (GSe). The company’s EBITDA targets represent 3%/6% of our current
2017/18 forecasts.

11:35 am
BE

And Citi.

BE

Whilst the Spanish deal was discussed in recent press speculation, the other acquisitions will be seen as a bonus. These deals help consolidate Just Eat’s market leadership positions within these countries. As highlighted in our recent note - Internet Traffic Trends Reassure: Pullback Provides Opportunity, Just Eat in Spain was thought to have c3x as much traffic going to its site than La Nevero Roja, and in Brazil, the iFood jv (30% Just Eat) was thought to have c80% of the online and mobile market. Just Eat confirmed today that iFood is the market leader in Brazil, and processed 1.1m orders in Dec15, +150% y-on-y.
The deals will be funded by cash (Citi est 2015e net cash c£195m). Management suggested accretion to 2016 adjusted EPS (net of one off costs), with c£5m accretion to 2017e EBITDA (Citi est £132.8m), and c£10m to 2018e (Citi est £167.6m).Despite a modest bounce yesterday, the share price has seen a material pull-back of late. At current levels Just Eat trades on only a Dec17e Ex-Cash P/E of 21.6x, 15.7x EV/EBITDA. We suggest this provides an opportunity to revisit the investment case ahead of FY15 results on 1st March. We maintain our 560p price target and Buy rating.

BE

Results from our review
• we saw a range of approaches to completing the appropriateness assessment, most of
which were not in line with COBS 10
• most risk warnings issued to clients who failed the appropriateness assessments were
not adequate
• anti-money laundering controls in place to manage the increased risks posed by higher
risk clients were insufficient
These findings also suggest that firms may not be acting in the best interests of their clients
and treating them fairly, bringing into question firms’ compliance with COBS 2.1.1R and the
Principles.
All firms operating in this sector should ensure that they comply with the FCA’s requirements when making non-advised sales of CFDs.

11:58 am
BE

Avoid Enterprise. That's the main conclusion.

BE

Here's page one.

BE

Incorporating balance sheet risks into ratings: The sell-off in high yield credit markets
has prompted us to look in detail at the balance sheets of the pub companies. With
Debt/EBITDAR of 5.8x, the sector remains amongst the most highly leveraged in the UK
market. Whilst we believe some leverage is appropriate, given the freehold backing, a
1% change in the sector EV should lead to a c3% change in equity value. Whilst we
have always considered FCF and ROIC as key investment issues, we add emphasis to
balance sheet strength as a factor that we believe is critical for investors. We see Greene
King (OW, PT raised to 990p) as the strongest all round company, with minimal near
term refinancing issues, a self-financing business model, significant headroom vs
covenants, and the best long term track record on capital allocation. We retain our
contrarian OW rating on Wetherspoon. Recent capital allocation has delivered very poor
returns for shareholders, but at such a low price point we see significant pent up
earnings potential via price rises, and maintain our view that it will deliver through the
cycle. We downgrade Enterprise Inns to UW (PT cut to 80p), given: i) the highest
Debt/EBITDA in the sector at 7.6x, ii) a £350m bond due for refinancing in 2018, and iii)
risks to earnings from the forthcoming Market Rent Only legislation. We remain UW on
Marston’s. The company is trading well, but it has a poor track record on net cash flow
and needs to issue new debt to maintain the new build expansion and equity dividend.
A move to a self-financing business model is a key upside risk to our current stance.

11:59 am
BE

Balance sheets: More to consider than just Debt/EBITDA: On a straight comparison
of Debt/EBITDA, Enterprise (7.6x FY16) and Punch (6.7x) look most at risk, whereas
Wetherspoon (3.4x ex-leases) looks well placed. Specifically focusing the conversion of
FCF into Net Cash Flow we see Marston’s and Mitchells & Butlers as poorly positioned,
both with cash outflows after securitisation amortisation. Greene King looks well placed
with a self-financed business model. JDW is also broadly net cash neutral over our
forecast period. Enterprise and Punch generate cash, but this is due to disposals.

BE

Unencumbered EBITDA and covenant strength compared: GNK (26% of EBITDA
unencumbered) and MARS (29%) have most financing flexibility. If trading worsens,
this means there is significant EBITDA outside secured debt structures to improve
covenant positions. Mitchells & Butlers also scores fairly well (18% of EBITDA
unencumbered), whereas Enterprise Inns (9%) and Punch Taverns (0%) score badly.

BE

Debt distribution: Despite the substantial debt positions, there are very few near term
financing pressures. Greene King’s bank debt expires in 2018, Marston’s in 2019, and
Wetherspoon’s in 2020. For GNK and MARS, bank debt is a small proportion of total
debt, and we have commented on the advantage they have from unencumbered assets.
JDW is highly dependent on bank debt but this is relatively long dated. Enterprise has
the nearest refinancing hurdle, with its £350m debenture due in 2018. Securitisation
amortisation profiles, although a drag on cash, are fairly smooth across the sector.

11:59 am

1. Further to Stock Exchange Notice N14/15 issued on 15 July 2015, which notified member firms of London Stock Exchange's ("the Exchange") intention to introduce a new intra-day auction for SETS equities, the Exchange can now confirm its implementation date of Monday 21 March 2016.

2. The intra-day auction will occur each London business day (except the two half-trading days at Christmas/New Year) at 12:00 Noon. As previously advised, it will consist of a two minute call period followed by a random 30 second period.
